content: quote: Originally posted by FrJohn1123: If Clinton and the republican congress could do it, it could be done again. I disagree. And here is why. We have been promised far too much over the past decade and we all know that it is impossible for government to ever CUT programs it has already begun. Medicare D and SCHIP to name but a few. And we are being promised Universal Health Care. But more so then that there are two other much larger problems. #1 The portion of the budget dedicated to paying interest just went up massively. The money has been borrowed. Short of stiffing the lenders we wont be getting that rather large chunk of our revenue back any time soon. And the enxt couple of budgets are already projecting trillion dollar deficits. #2 Under Clinton/Repub congress a good portion of the budget was funded from surplus social security revenue. That too is shrinking as time goes by. The further into the baby boom retirement we go the less of that there will be. We will need to raise taxes just to continue spending at the rates we are today as a larger and larger percentage of the FICA revenue stream actually goes to social security and medicare.
quote: Originally posted by FrJohn1123: If Clinton and the republican congress could do it, it could be done again.
reply: I disagree. And here is why. We have been promised far too much over the past decade and we all know that it is impossible for government to ever CUT programs it has already begun. Medicare D and SCHIP to name but a few. And we are being promised Universal Health Care. But more so then that there are two other much larger problems. #1 The portion of the budget dedicated to paying interest just went up massively. The money has been borrowed. Short of stiffing the lenders we wont be getting that rather large chunk of our revenue back any time soon. And the enxt couple of budgets are already projecting trillion dollar deficits. #2 Under Clinton/Repub congress a good portion of the budget was funded from surplus social security revenue. That too is shrinking as time goes by. The further into the baby boom retirement we go the less of that there will be. We will need to raise taxes just to continue spending at the rates we are today as a larger and larger percentage of the FICA revenue stream actually goes to social security and medicare.
title: Blue dogs introduce paygo bill

content: quote: I disagree. And here is why. we managed to do it after the depression and WWII. and(acounting for inflation) we borrowed and spent much more than we are now. and that was also after the new deal and many many more government programs in place. i believe we can and will. To me the only question is "how long will it take".

content: quote: Originally posted by karlhungusjr: quote: I disagree. And here is why. we managed to do it after the depression and WWII. and(acounting for inflation) we borrowed and spent much more than we are now. and that was also after the new deal and many many more government programs in place. i believe we can and will. To me the only question is "how long will it take". There are a number of significant differences between the United States of the 30s and 40s and today. The most obvious is that we have a population that is significantly larger yet the same number or less of nearly every resource this land can provide. Example #1. In the 40s the United States was the world's largest exporter of OIL. Today we are the largest importer. We are a significantly older society today then we were in the 30s & 40s. The average age of our citizens has increased significantly. And that is important when we consider programs like social security and medicare which by the way have been expanded significantly since the 30s and 40s. Needless to say we are sharing the same size pie with a much larger number of people. Not only a larger american citizenry but also a world full of people that are beginning to pull themselves out of their aguarian base and into a modern industrial society. The world is a very different place. its population is beginning to butt up with the natural limits of its resources. Scarcity of all sorts will be the name of the game moving forward. Example #2 was global warming a major concern in the 40s?
quote: Originally posted by karlhungusjr: quote: I disagree. And here is why. we managed to do it after the depression and WWII. and(acounting for inflation) we borrowed and spent much more than we are now. and that was also after the new deal and many many more government programs in place. i believe we can and will. To me the only question is "how long will it take".
reply: There are a number of significant differences between the United States of the 30s and 40s and today. The most obvious is that we have a population that is significantly larger yet the same number or less of nearly every resource this land can provide. Example #1. In the 40s the United States was the world's largest exporter of OIL. Today we are the largest importer. We are a significantly older society today then we were in the 30s & 40s. The average age of our citizens has increased significantly. And that is important when we consider programs like social security and medicare which by the way have been expanded significantly since the 30s and 40s. Needless to say we are sharing the same size pie with a much larger number of people. Not only a larger american citizenry but also a world full of people that are beginning to pull themselves out of their aguarian base and into a modern industrial society. The world is a very different place. its population is beginning to butt up with the natural limits of its resources. Scarcity of all sorts will be the name of the game moving forward. Example #2 was global warming a major concern in the 40s?

content: quote: Originally posted by karlhungusjr: quote: I disagree. And here is why. we managed to do it after the depression and WWII. and(acounting for inflation) we borrowed and spent much more than we are now. and that was also after the new deal and many many more government programs in place. i believe we can and will. To me the only question is "how long will it take". There are a number of significant differences between the United States of the 30s and 40s and today. The most obvious is that we have a population that is significantly larger yet the same number or less of nearly every resource this land can provide. Example #1. In the 40s the United States was the world's largest exporter of OIL. Today we are the largest importer. We are a significantly older society today then we were in the 30s & 40s. The average age of our citizens has increased significantly. And that is important when we consider programs like social security and medicare which by the way have been expanded significantly since the 30s and 40s. Needless to say we are sharing the same size pie with a much larger number of people. Not only a larger american citizenry but also a world full of people that are beginning to pull themselves out of their aguarian base and into a modern industrial society. The world is a very different place. its population is beginning to butt up with the natural limits of its resources. Scarcity of all sorts will be the name of the game moving forward. Example #2 was global warming a major concern in the 40s?
quote: Originally posted by karlhungusjr: quote: I disagree. And here is why. we managed to do it after the depression and WWII. and(acounting for inflation) we borrowed and spent much more than we are now. and that was also after the new deal and many many more government programs in place. i believe we can and will. To me the only question is "how long will it take".
reply: There are a number of significant differences between the United States of the 30s and 40s and today. The most obvious is that we have a population that is significantly larger yet the same number or less of nearly every resource this land can provide. Example #1. In the 40s the United States was the world's largest exporter of OIL. Today we are the largest importer. We are a significantly older society today then we were in the 30s & 40s. The average age of our citizens has increased significantly. And that is important when we consider programs like social security and medicare which by the way have been expanded significantly since the 30s and 40s. Needless to say we are sharing the same size pie with a much larger number of people. Not only a larger american citizenry but also a world full of people that are beginning to pull themselves out of their aguarian base and into a modern industrial society. The world is a very different place. its population is beginning to butt up with the natural limits of its resources. Scarcity of all sorts will be the name of the game moving forward. Example #2 was global warming a major concern in the 40s?
title: Blue dogs introduce paygo bill
